39102256.review:
This is a really great game and is cute, funny, and engaging. The main objective is to coordinate your airstrip and land planes, but there so many other little elements in this game that stand out. You use a fire hose to put out planes that are on fire, you have to scare birds off of the runway using an air horn, and you have to throw baggage to the right plane, all while under pressure to get everything done as fast as you can. It can get stressful, but it's really a blast and has been a hit at parties.

There's a good depth to this game with many different elements and mechanics, so it has good replayability. It was worth the price and I bought it again as a gift. This is one of those games that's only possible in VR and I would recommend it.

38679714.review:
This game hits close to home for me as a professional in this industry. I write a lengthy review in the hopes that it will reach the development team if they ever update the game. 

It was super fun at first. Metro Airport is by far the most compelling level, and the flawless challenge was addicting as hell, trying to manage 3 runways and running unnecessarily aggressive squeeze plays with airliners is so fun. The amount of close calls when I land on 2L and launch on 11 causes serious and hilarious tension. You have to learn to keep track of who you clear and where, because if you forget one, people die. In the time I played, I definitely felt myself get more and more competent managing traffic, spacing adequately and limiting the number of collisions and making it farther and farther each time. Big airports were what this game was designed for, and I was disappointed to see there was only one. It was a lot of fun for the first two hours.

As I got better and better, I noticed things that were clearly rushed in development, as if “small” issues were deferred to meet deadlines and push the game out. Understandable, but I was operating under the impression that I had little value as a controller in this world, that the game didn’t have any respect for the magnitude of responsibility of safely controlling airplanes. 

My first and biggest issue was with the ground vehicles. They don’t stop for airplanes, they will randomly drive onto and stop on active runways, and sometimes at the north terminal the catering truck will crash into the airplane that’s safely parked at the northeast-most gate. The catering truck will sometimes just spawn up north right next to an airplane I have holding short of 11 and ram into it. Once, just off 2L, I had to stop taxiing an airliner because the catering truck was approaching. The catering truck stopped directly in front of the airplane for about five seconds, giving the ambulance ample time to approach from the north and ram full-speed into the side of the airplane, forcing me to start over. Instead of being cautious and meticulous, the ground vehicles are random and reckless. It seems like they are actively trying to run into the airplanes. I understand the need for an additional micromanagement challenge, but I feel this is more a “random death chance” mechanic that was just poorly executed. It’s immensely demoralizing to be on a roll sequencing and spacing just to have a round cut short by a rogue ground vehicle. 

Next, sometimes the auto-pathing of uncontrolled aircraft will cause them to randomly have a mid-air collision. Focused on sequencing and boom, a random midair on the other side of the map and the round is over. 

Lastly, the UI just seems unimpressive. It’s not necessarily bad, just unwieldy, as if they designed it on day 1 and never improved it. 

This game was way fun at first and I’d recommend the initial experience as money well-spent on a VR game. However the aforementioned issues above caused me to prematurely give up in frustration.

36289148.review:
This game is an example of some of the creative new genres being made possible by VR.  The core of the game is built around air traffic control and guiding planes through landing and take off while keeping them from crashing into each other.  Sounds kind of "plane" but its actually a lot more fun than it sounds.  

The gameplay is quite original.  You use your hand to touch planes and draw a line in the air to give them a flight path.  Better keep the lines smooth and the turns gradual or they might crash.  A small plane might be able to make a tight turn but a jumbo jet can't.  There are also lots of mini games you have to keep on top of to keep things running like loading bags into the right carts, shooing birds off the runway and putting out the occasional engine fire.  On the Navy fleet level you can defend the fleet with some anti-aircraft guns.

There are quite a few locations and levels.  From the lonely island airport to the international airport, to the big city, to the navy fleet.  The first levels are easy and laid back but as you progress youve got to handle things quickly.  There are always multiple things going on at once at the international airport.  Once youve mastered the missions the challenge levels will definitely keep you busy.  They take a lot of effort to perfect.

The visuals are as good as the video and screenshots indicate.  Even though it is cartoony looking it is still highly detailed.  You'll find yourself kneeling down to the floor occasionally to look at all the tiny buildings and structures.

Overall this game is a great value for it's current price of $15.  My friends and I have spent almost 10 hours on this game and still haven't seen everything yet.  It's one of the more unique games on VR and one I keep coming back to from time to time.

This game is a ludicrous amount of fun and seriously evokes that feeling of having your own little living toybox in front of you.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0rpoRHCnVWc

If you've ever played the mobile game Flight Control, you already know what to expect here. There's an airport, there are planes in the air, get them on the ground without killing anyone. It's such a simple concept but in VR it just takes on a whole new lease on life. Ever aerial vehicle in the game is no more than 2 inches big and because of how VR works, it genuinely looks like someones breathed life into some adorable toys.

It's fun, it's challenging, it's gorgeous. With so many little extra mechanics added on to add a little flavour to your gameplay. Plane landed because of a fire? Shrink yourself down onto the tarmac, grab a hose and put it out. Generator died? Get one of your resident repair choppers to airlift it out and replace it with a new one.

Don't want to go through the campaign? That's fine too. There's all kinds of extra challenge missions to complete, including repelling an alien attack while guiding aircraft through to safety.

These devs have made a wonderful experience and quite honestly at a fantastic price point too. For the content present, you get more than your moneys worth. I cannot reccomend it enough. :D

32786814.review:
Kennt ihr diese Handy Spiele, bei denen man einen Flughafen von oben sieht und Flugzeugen verschiedene Start- und Landebahnen zuweist und dafür sorgen muss, dass diese nicht kollidieren?
Wenn nicht, solltet ihr euch so etwas mal ansehen, das ist recht spaßig als kurzes Casual Game.

Final Approach nimmt dieses Spielprinzip und setzt es in den dreidimensionalen Raum. Man steht also vor einem hübsch gemachten Minitaurflughafen (wie Godzilla *muahaha*). Flugzeuge und Helikopter schwirrren herum und man malt einen dreidimensionalen Pfad in die Luft den sie auf die zugewiesene Landebahn nehmen sollen, weist Terminals zu und lässt sie wieder starten. Es gibt zusätzlich noch kurze Mini-einsätze, wie bspw. Brände löschen, Alienangriffe etc. bei denen man selbst tätig werden muss, das lockert das ganze noch zusätzlich auf.

Es gibt klasse Herausforderungen, die zunehmen schwieriger werden und in einem für VR genau richtigen Umfang sind. Final Approach ist ein Super Spiel, das das Medium VR extrem gut nutzt, eine gesunde Portion Hektik verbreitet und sich anfühlt als würde man mit seinen lebendig gewordenen Matchbox Sachen spielen. Die Grafik und der Sound sinf gut und die Steuerung ist intuitiv und funktioniert super. Es ist auch abseits der vielen Shooter und Bogenspiele eine frische und bestens umgesetzte Idee. Man benötigt allerdings einen gewissen Spielbereich, 1-2qm sollten es sein.

Außerdem kommt das ganze in einem Bundle mit einer "Pilot Edition" die man keinesfalls einzeln kaufen sollte, denn sie ist bestens dazu geeignet, dass man nach wenigen Sekunden einem Eimer braucht um zu demonstrieren, was bei exzessiver Motion Sickness passiert *g*

Final Approach ist meiner Meinung nach ein Pflichtkauf für VR Besitzer.

31437819.review:
Holy crap this game. Transforms me into a little kid with the greatest playset of all time. Essentially, you have toy-sized planes flying into your room and you have to give them a flight path to the airstrip while avoiding crashing into other planes (if you've ever played the mobile game Flight Control, it's a very similar idea).

This is of itself really entertaining and can get pretty frantic. What really brings in the 'holy crap' experience is the ground tasks. Occasionally, you'll have to help out on the airfield (e.g. helping douse the flames on a burning plane that's made an emergency landing or clearing birds off the airfield). Suddenly the little 'toys' you've been playing with, the miniature airfield playset, are writ large. A hundred metres off, you can see the jumbo airliner you just guided down to the airstrip, the thumb-sized bus you had to steer one of the little gliders around is now passing by you, and it's the size of a bus! Something about seeing the whole scene you've been standing over suddenly and dramatically in life size reinforces the god-like role of the player. It's a unique and almost humbling experience. 

Then you realise you've been staring too long and two new planes that appeared while you were chasing birds crash into each other miles above. Oops.

11/10 would play god again.

28404261.review: Oh wow, I finally got to play this version with the Oculus Touch and this is really impressive.  It's a toybox fantasy - think of those tilt-shift timelapse videos that make cityscapes look like tiny train-set environments.  This has that vibe going on, with tiny, beautiful, immaculately detailed aircraft flying around your head (with really nice positional sound - you know exactly where everything is by audio alone).  I haven't played a whole lot yet, and the store screenshots concern me that the missions might get gimmicky, but I don't care because I can see myself just chilling and playing the freeplay mode for hours on end.  As a VR experience, this is delightful and well worth the bucks just because of all the tiny little planes and how satisfying it is to be among them, guide them smoothly home, and miscalculate their flight dynamics horribly, leaving them to explode into the ground with horrifying regularity.  I really don't see how there hasn't been an investigation into these incidents yet.

25417935.review:
I spent $30 on what is effectively a VR mobile game.

Planes fly into your roomscale space and you have to draw a line to a landing pad and they follow the path. Occasionally a plane is on fire - you have to teleport to the ground and spray it. Sometimes birds show up on the ground. You onto the ground and scare them off. Then you tap on planes waiting to take off, then they take off.

That's the first level.

The second is an international airport where you land jumbo jets, draw lines to move them to get to terminals, repair planes, and airlift generators onto roofs and switch them on.

All in all it's just a whole lot of... not much. The ideas in the game feel VERY disjointed. It seems like the developers sat there and asked themselves "What can we do to make this more difficult? - Right! We can make cars drive around an international airport and crash into your planes unless you stop them!" For someone playing with air control, the game doesn't seem to respect the fact that the player is put into a position of care and basically just tries to fuck up your efforts 'to make it harder.'

It's a mish mash of elements that artifically bulk up what is effectively a very easy 'draw a line and land some planes' game. People say it's one of the more beautiful games but I'd disagree. The UI feels asthetically disjointed, the controller models are disjointed, the scale feels very wrong and the level design doesn't feel credible in the slightest.

If you enjoy multitasking little mini games for long periods of time, then this game is for you. This game isn't personally rewarding and beats you to the ground with boring, simple tasks.
25417935.developer_response: Hi there! Feedback like this is extremely important to us when looking at ways to balance the game and give new players incentives to move through the game. We paced the content throughout the first few levels to gradually add new gameplay elements for players, slowly increasing in difficulty and complexity. We've seen other feedback like yours that let us know the intro levels just don't show that to new players. In response, we've unlocked the first 7 levels of the game after you complete the intro, which we think is ample room to experience all the maps and a wide variety of gameplay. We hope you'll give it a shot, thanks for playing!

Summary: Final Approach is easily one of my favorite VR games. The amount of polish and overall content is more than I've seen in nearly all other VR titles. I'm not an aviation enthusiast AT ALL, but that didn't stop me from having a good time. There is something very satisfying of taking over a stressful air-traffic control job (and more!) in VR. With the recent addition of Final Approach: Pilot Edition (included when you buy Final Approach), this game is easily worth the asking price.

+Includes Pilot Edition

Ho preso questo gioco pensando che poi avrei chiesto subito il rimborso, ma devo ricredermi! 
Non fate l'errore di pensare che questo gioco sia solamente controllare il volo in 3D,è molto di più! i video e le foto non rendono giustizia a questa piccola perla per HTC Vive, ci vorrebbe una demo almeno della prima missione! 
Questo gioco è molto raffinato e curato, se lo avessi saputo prima non avrei mai penstato di comprarlo per provarlo e chiedere il rimborso, ma attualmente sulla VR ci sono molti giochi che sono solamente delle demo estremamente costose, che stanno a mio avviso rovinando un po il mercato, fortunatamente Final Approach non fa parte di questa categoria!
Ci sono missioni ben equilibrate e impegnative, ed un sacco di mini-giochi.
Oltre a guidare gli aerei/elicotteri dovrete, trasportare casse, merci, spegnere gli incendi hai vari veicoli, salvataggio piloti abbattutti o persone in difficoltà, sparare agli aerei nemici e anche catturare gli alieni. 
Nelle missioni avanzate diventa molto affollato, trovo sempre molto bello zommare in prima persona (dove ci si sente come un bambino con i sui giocattoli) dove in un attimo vi troverete improvvisamente per esempio affianco ad un aereo in fiamme e spegnerete un incendio con in mano la vostra manichetta dell'acqua in perfetto stile pompiere.
Questo a mio parere è uno dei migliori giochi per la realtà virtuale al momento disponibile!
Zero nausa anche dopo oltre mezz'ora di gioco continuata, grafica curata e dettagliata, in italiano.
Altamente raccomandato.

Very solid offering in VR, one of the most complete games out there. A good value because as of this time (7/15/16) if you buy it, you get the seated Final Approach pilot edition as well, which while similar puts a whole new twist of allowing you to actually pilot the planes. I look at it as a whole package let’s call it Final Approach :Definitive Edition.   

I still like the room scale version better though, it’s such a kick to go stomping around the airports like some kind of giant, plucking planes and helos out of the sky to do your bidding.  

The game itself is an Air Traffic control sim, but takes a more arcade approach to it, you aren't just staring at a screen spitting out call signs and tail numbers. You are right in the midst of the action, creating flight paths, rescuing planes that need an emergency landing. You will also tackle a variety of other aviation related tasks, from being zoomed down to ground view to put out fires, or scare away birds on the run way with an air horn, and later there’s even more stuff to do, taxing airliners to their terminals, sending others of to get repaired, picking up cargo with a helicopter, ferrying around works to work sites to improve the terminal.  There's even more but I haven’t got to it yet. 

All in all I'd say 8.5 out of 10
During a time when it seems like most of what you find are overblown tech demos, or repetition of decent idea (Do we really need another Zombie wave fighter?)  Final Approach manages to stand out as full bodied product and even if you don't have a special interest in aviation this game is well worth checking out.

24239383.review:
TL;DR: When it's good, it's great! When it's bad, you might break something in frustration.

First, I'll forewarn by saying... I only wrote this when I ran into something I could complain about.

In the beginning, this is a casual puzzler with a lot of mini-game objectives. It's downright pleasant to sweep along and draw lines to the different runways. In fact, it feels a lot like playing with an active airplane miniature set. Fantastic! Putting out planes on fire. (Which should be alarming how often that happens.) To clearing birds off the runway. To even guiding planes to embark and disembark. Although, I could deal without baggage handling... I ran into a spat of bad luck and the randomization ran me 20 bags without the one I needed and there were only three colors to choose from.

Suddenly, they make you shoot things... a lot. With just that have poor AI guidance, to boot. When I target an "objective" and it doesn't shoot on it's own when I use another plane to target another "objective"? Or, the turrets you put in place for one mission don't shoot all the time... and your poor little F16 who can barely turn in the airspace with six hovering opponents?

Rocket lock on. C'mon! Picking up bad guys off the ground with a helicopter that doesn't "pivot" it swings wide like someone who doesn't know how to park a truck. Pop! Another helicopter down. And when my jet decides to run off and die without my guidance? And I still get docked for bad AI? Grrr... This becomes a lesson in gameplay testing. Srsly.

Then... knocking missiles out of the sky? You ram them with another plane. Easy peasy. There's no other way to take them out because they have hella armor, apparently. So, sacrifice is key. (Take one for the team, pilot!)

What I'm trying to say... difficulty doesn't "scale" it spikes like a angry jock... and you'll find yourself sweating over some damn fires on a rooftop while "bad guys" are shooting up your world. After the 15 mission, I felt like someone got lazy in the story mode. There really is barely any difference from three star ratings to failing the mission.

Still, the good is very good in this game. It's a feat of luck when you squeak by on certain missions, however.

23826473.review:
Final Approach is a fun air traffic control game that I can see a lot of people enjoying. It really works to the strengths of current VR tech, especially as a room-scale title.

The presentation is great: you're thrown into a miniature world with aircraft buzzing around your head. It makes me feel like a kid again, playing with some sort of magical airplane playset from the future!

The controls are intuitive, and the gameplay has more depth to it than it might seem at first. It's one of the few current VR titles that I'm enjoying for the gameplay, as well as the novelty factor. 

There's a really nice feature to scale the play-area independently of the SteamVR room settings, which is a GREAT touch. This means that you can shrink the world to make it easier to move around & lift or drop the floor height so you can play comfortably.

There are a couple of minor grumbles: the voice-overs get annoyingly repetitive very quickly, as do the break-out interactions like putting out fires & scaring away birds. 

Otherwise, it's a fantastic game into which the developers have clearly put a lot of love & attention. I would recommend this without hesitation to anyone who wants a good casual game that shows off VR in a subtle but well-done way.

Here's the thing ... I don't like these kinds of games.

But the way they implemented it is amazing!   

I find the "landing plan" sim thing to be a little frustrating for my tastes.   It  doesn't scratch my particular itch.    But the smooth and beautiful way this little world is rendered, and the playful way you can nip down to ground level, play at putting out a fire or fixing some other issue, and then nip back out to your giant-view to continue playing.

It makes me immediately wish for a God-Game like Populous, but done by this amazing company!

They perfectly capture the necessary Reality of a giant-view tabletop display, and integrate your actions directly into the world.

In another iteration and with a few tweaks we could be ordering squads of elves to defend against legions of orcs, or playing Descent: Journeys in the Dark or Imperial Assault, or Heroquest with animated heroes.

So play this game, support this company, and see what they do next!   

Because if it keeps *me* coming back for more just for the world, then it doesn't even matter that this is a fantastic game that just doesn't happen to do it for me.

A very good, challenging game that provides an amount of content and gameplay worthy of the price. For my full thoughts on the game, you can watch my [url=https://youtu.be/NsetcpQcC1M] video review here. [/url]

Please note that my playtime is not accurately represented here, as this isn't my primary account used for gaming.

A few other things I've noted since making the review:

[*]The tutorial does mention that planes can't take too sharp turns, so not to draw sharp paths. Perhaps a warning (at the very least, in the tutorial) displaying when you draw a path too sharp would help people get an idea of what kind of turning angles they can pull off.
[*]Free Mode stages don't unlock until you play in each environment for the first time, but challenge levels are all unlocked after playing the tutorial only. Not sure if this was intended or not.
[*]Scaring off gulls becomes too easy, as they always appear in the same exact locations. It only takes a few times until you know exactly where you need to aim your air horn, making the task take easily under 2 seconds. This kind of makes it not much of a task at all, certainly no challenge. Perhaps make the seagulls spawn in random locations, or maybe in different group sizes. ゴッドシムとし自分自身がジオラマに神として存在して航空機に指令を出すRTSです。
VRの本格ゴッドシムは面白そうですね。

自分にとってはリプレイ性の高いゲームです。
クリアすべき課題は面ごとに固定ですが、飛行機の出現位置などはランダムのため同じ面をプレイしてもそれなりに楽しいです。
一度アンロックしてしまえば遊びたい面を指定して遊べます。

通常のゲーム同様にグラフィックの設定オプションがあります。
Anti-Aliasing 0/2/4/8
Shadow Quality Low/Mid/High/Very High
GeForce 970だと両方共最低にしてもプレイに支障はありませんがたまにコマ落ちしています。
Defaultは、Anti-Aliasing 2/Shadow Quality MidでGeForce 970でゲームプレイに支障はありません。

VR専用ルームスケール対応ゲームは、新鮮です。
飛行機を掴んで子供が遊ぶように「ぶ～～ん」と行き先を指示。

[Updated Review]

After taking a second look at the game (sorry for the late response, Devs) my first Gripe has pretty much been erased.

Before, the Ingame Ground pretty much matched the real ground in my room, after changing the setting I would guess it's more around waist height and playing is MUCH more comfortable.

[Original Review]

This game has a lot of potential but at least at this moment it isn't the game for me.

I liked the early "ATC" games on my first iPad where you had to essentially do the same thing as here just in 2d - the same applies to this game, however my fun is severly dampened by two things in particular.

On the plus side I feel like those two things are easily changed IF the developers want to add the options for that.

Gripe #1:
The Height of the play area.
Now, it might be due to the fact that i'm a big person but while playing the game I really felt like... imagine you'd have to play with your three year old cousin and he's sitting on the ground but you have to stand and play with him that way. You're always leaning over and after a while, your back isn't exactly enjoying itself.

A possible fix to that would be to have the airport raised like on a table. If you've tried Valves Bow and Arrow demo and the Castle miniature you get a good understanding of what i mean. For example a living room with a big table and on that table sits the "playset" (would fit in with the feeling of "playing with Micro Machines")
That way, your back won't hurt after a while and you enjoy the game more. If the Devs would include that as an option I'd be very thankfull.

Gripe #2:
The frequency of "sh*t goes wrong" - now I get you want the game to be a challenge but I just felt like I'm doing nothing BUT shooing away seagulls and extinguising fires. That may be down to the fact that i'm not a great player at this or something but I would appreciated a more "relaxed" mode. In my opinion it was just "too much" and I ended up not enjoying the game anymore and just exiting - which is a shame because, as I said, I really enjoy the Idea behind the game.

So if those two gripes were to be adressed in later patches, I'd definitely change my recommendation for that game.

As it stands, the way it is now and from my point of view I would not recommend it, although your view may differ and perhaps you don't mind the two gripes I've mentioned.

-Gextroll signing off. o7
22893180.developer_response:
Thanks for playing and leaving your feedback. We want to address a few of your concerns:

#1 Scale: We have an existing feature in the game that allows you to change the height/scale within the settings menu. You can also view how to do this in the sticky thread here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/380670/discussions/0/364040166673217626/

This was a big issue throughout development and feedback we got from many of our playtesters and something we made sure was in the initial build. 

#2 Frequency: Currently we have the zoom-point events on a random rotation. We can definitely see how this could get repetitive for some players, especially in early levels. This is something we want to balance in future updates by adding variety to these tasks and optimizing the frequency of these tasks occurring. 


We hope to add more of what you're looking for in regards to #2 in upcoming updates, so please look out for those! We'd love to have you play again and give us your feedback on future changes. Thanks again for leaving such honest feedback- with your help, we improve!

22784010.review:
Final Approach offers a unique experience that demonstrates the incredible potential of the HTC Vive. Not only do you play a third-person strategy game where you serve the role as an aircraft controller, but you're able to warp down to ground level and do a few different mini-tasks such as putting out fires with a water hose, or throwing luggage into destination containers. The transition between third-person and first-person is downright remarkable, presenting a perspective that makes the world come to life.

Final Approach suffers from some repetition as with the entire HTC Vive launch line-up, but does present several missions that are moderate in length. Because of this, it is one of the games that I foresee offering some of the longest-duration play value. 

I would recommend Final Approach as one of the top three options for HTC Vive launch as it's unique and should provide around four+ hours of entertainment.

You can read more about my impressions here: http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/final-approach-on-htc-vive-shows-how-multiperspective-vr-games-can-blow-your-mind

When I was a kid, my friends and I would fly die-cast toy fighters around the house, dogfighting according to a set of rules that were never made explicit but which we followed nonetheless. 22608256.review:
This is not "Just "Flight Control" in 3D". 

I thought that too, and even though it's mostly true, such a description is VASTLY underselling this game. For starters, you're underestimating how much depth adds to the experience, now you need to consider where the plane is in 3D space as well as what approach angle you've drawn, as planes can't turn on a dime.

There's also a lot more depth than Flight Control. You're doing far more than simply landing planes, you also need to take them off too, which requires you to pay attention and make sure there's a clear run. Different planes also have different requirements, passenger planes need to be taken to the terminal before they can take off again and military planes need to go to the military hanger before take-off. There's also things like emergencies that require you to personally extinguish a burning plane or simply help out with luggage sorting. 

In later stages, you do more than just land planes. You might be piloting a helicopter to catch a criminal and drop them off at the police station or fighting UFOs with fighter jets and turrets (which you can also personally control in first person view.

And finally, the game has a loving level of attention to detail in the visuals. They're not just well-made but despite the zoomed-out view of the game, there's still lots of little details to see if you come in close. The whole game feels like you're looking at a little model railroad! It's a big departure from similar games that cut corners because they figure you probably won't see it.

So yeah, Final Approach is a great game, it's had a lot of attention and polish applied that fits it's "premium" price. If you're passing on it because you think its quality and depth will be that of a mobile game, you're sorely mistaken!

This is one of the most fun and addicting games I have played in VR to date.  It was actually one of the games I played on a demo Vive Pre that convinced me to preorder it.

Usually I don't write a whole lot of reviews but after getting further along in this game, I feel that I really need to offer it.  This is especially because this game gets a whole lot better as you move along.  The progress of the game allows you to learn and pick up skills.  Then it gets a lot more intense.

You start by directing slow aircraft on an island.  Then you move up to a commercial airport.  Then you direct helicopters in the middle of a metropolis.

The last stage I played convinced me to write this review.  You get to direct fighter aircraft to land on an aircraft carrier!  In every stage you are able to get to the ground level to put out fires.  This includes fires on aircraft.  So, I actually got to stand on an aircraft carrier as a full-sized naval fighter jet taxied past me.  I felt like I could actually touch the sidewinder missiles!  I looked to the left to see ground crew prepping or repairing other fighters.

There are some other incredibly fun things you can do in this stage but I think I have already provided enough spoilers!

Get this game.  It is beautiful, complete, and intense!

22373960.review:
So this game is pretty cool.

I loaded it up with the expectation that it'll be like the Ipad type games, where you're basically just dragging planes to runways. But that's not all! There's fires you have to put out, seagulls you have to chase away and many switches to flip. 

Being able to hear the planes zip in and around your head really made me feel like some sort of technological god guiding planes and passengers to safety. Being able to bend down to really look at each and every plane, building and employee in detail really helped to add to that experience, and I could actually spend a while just staring at the gorgeous environment around me.

There is a surprising amount of depth to this game, but that said it can get a little repetitive if you're not following the campaign. You're really just repeating the same things over and over until you get overwhelmed if you play the free-play (which I spend a bit of time doing) so after a while I find myself just letting everything go to the crapper and appreciating  how useless airport staff is without a godlike figure doing every little job for them.

Definitely worth checking out, particularly while it is on sale; this game is certainly one of my VR experiences that I thoroughly enjoyed.

22301837.review:
I actually feel bad now about waiting to buy this for $20. This game is so much better than what I was expecting. The detail, my gosh, the detail. I was blown away by the opening screen, even. The menus are gorgeous and perfect for VR, the planes look amazing, and there is a surprising amount of variety in the gameplay. 

This game is SO MUCH MORE than simply drawing flight routes for planes to land (a-la Air Control for mobile platform). That's what I was expecting, and it's there, but oh my, it's only a tiny part. This is a perfect example of a game that doesn't convey it's beauty from demo vids or pictures. Maybe consider releasing a short demo of the first mission? I bought this because it looked interesting, the dev seemed really nice from interviews before Vive release, and I really appreciated their communication about the initial sticker shock and subsequent price drop. 

Had I known the game was this polished, with so much variety, I would not have cared about the aforementioned reasons for the purchase. This game is a blast, plain and simple. Can't wait to get out of work so I can get back to it! 

Love planes? You'll probably really enjoy Final Approach. Me262 taxiing to the runway ready for take-off? Yes please

This is a bit of a tough one for me.  The quality and polish is really really high.  The gameplay isn't bad, but I just found it to be a little... slow and simple.  I think kids will LOVE this because it's basically playing with a big toy set.

I think the current price ($30 @ 25% off) is warranted given the amount of effort and quality put into the game, but I don't know if it's something I personally would get $30 worth of fun out of, particularly given the competitive launch lineup.

If the prospect of standing like a giant over an airport and playing with it like toys sounds like something you would really really be into, then go ahead and pull the trigger.  If not, it's probably worth waiting on a price drop.
